frameDefinitions: A Cognizer produces a Target_symbol which represents, in the Target_representation format, a Content that pre-exists in the form of a Source_symbol in a Source_representation format. ''  'This word is sometimes  translated as ` girl '.
One linguistic unit, Sign_1, has a relation to another linguistic unit, Sign_2.
An Entity is affected by an Event.
A person (Speaker) expresses a Message or mental content, broadly understood, in a particular Manner.
In this frame a Deformer deforms a Patient possibly against a Resistant_surface such that it undergoes a shape-change from its canonical or original shape into the Configuration, a new shape.
A Speaker realizes a Sign, usually a linguistic one, in some Formal_realization.
frameExamples: This word is sometimes <t>translated</t> as ` girl '. CNI
The hotel is <t>undergoing</t> renovations at this time.
Ellen <t>crumpled</t> the paper into a ball.
A person doesn't always <t>pronounce</t> a word the way they say  it in context
listRoleDefinitions: This is the person who carries out the translation.
A symbol or set of symbols representing the <fen>Content</fen> in the <fen>Source_representation</fen> format.
The representation system in which the <fen>Content</fen> pre-exists.
A symbol or set of symbols representing the <fen>Content</fen> in the <fen>Target_representation</fen> format.
The representation system into which the <fen>Content</fen> is rendered by the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The information that is meant to be represented by the <fen>Source_symbol</fen> and <fen>Target_symbol</fen>.
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate when a certain Categorization was made.
The location where the translation takes place.
FN: a linguistic unit that carries semantic, phonological or syntactic information.
FN: a linguistic unit
FN: Linguistic units
The thing which is affected by the Event.
A change in the world which affects the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Entity</fen> undergoes the <fen>Event</fen>.
The location at which the <fen>Entity</fen> undergoes the <fen>Event</fen>.
<fen>Speaker</fen>, the person who encodes the <fen>Message</fen>, occurs as the External Argument of all the verbs:
The <fen>Message</fen> is almost invariably expressed in an NP Object. (The only exceptions occur with the verb <t>express</t>, which is occasionally used with that-clause complements.)

For most of the words in this frame, some expression of <fen>Manner</fen> or <fen>Medium</fen> is obligatory. As in other frames, <fen>Manner</fen> expressions characterize the action (in this case, the speech act performed by the <fen>Speaker</fen>). However, a wide range of <fen>Manner</fen> expressions occurs in this frame, including the following types:
<fen>Medium</fen> expresses the <fen>Medium</fen> of communication, such as the language used or the specific type of text in which the <fen>Message</fen> occurs:
The <fen>Deformer</fen> is the one who does the reshaping.
The <fen>Patient</fen> is the entity acted on and that undergoes a change.
The <fen>Cause</fen> is an animate or inanimate entity, a force, or event that produces an effect. Volitionality is not a necessary characteristic of <fen>Cause</fen>s.
A state that holds of the <fen>Patient</fen> or a relation that holds among the constituent parts of the <fen>Patient</fen> as a result of the arranging action.
The role <fen>Time</fen> identifies when the <fen>Deformer</fen> intentionally affects the <fen>Patient</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> indicates where the <fen>Deformer</fen> intentionally affects the <fen>Patient</fen>.
The language user who produces a <fen>Sign</fen> in some modality.
An abstract form-meaning pairing.
An evaluation of whether the <fen>Formal_realization</fen> that the <fen>Speaker</fen> produced matches the standard or standard range.
The written string, gesture, or vocalized sound sequence that the <fen>Speaker</fen> produces.
A constituent part of the <fen>Formal_realization</fen>.
The way that the <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Formal_realization</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Formal_realization</fen>.
listRoleExamples:
The text was published in Lescarbot's Les Muses de la Nouvelle-France (Paris
1609) and later translated <fex>by HT Richardson</fex>.
Biblical scholars typically translate <fex>kenosis</fex> as self-emptying or self-offering.
More books were translated <fex>from other languages</fex> into Russian in the 1980s , including record numbers from English , German and French.
Together with the French Prime Minister, Guizot, he translated it into French <fex>as entente cordiale</fex> for King Louis Philippe to use in his speech.
Well they translated it <fex>into Spanish</fex> as 'Uno-Dos-Tres Meneha Meneha!'
She guided me through the dishes available that afternoon and translated <fex>my order</fex> into Spanish for the older woman in the kitchen.
<fex>Last year</fex> I translated a short book on the artist Anne Ratkowski (of the pre-war November Group in Berlin) from German into English.
In one sense, <fex>dog</fex> is a hyponym of itself.
In one sense, dog is a hyponym of <fex>itself</fex>.
<fex>Happy and sad</fex> are antonyms.
<fex>The teacher</fex> phrased the question carefully.
The Prime Minister expressed <fex>her sympathy for the victims</fex>.
True Manner: You should phrase it <fex>carefully</fex>.
Kim formulated her objections <fex>in French</fex>.
<fex>The lieutenant</fex> crushed it angrily with his boot before looking back at Hencke.
Jack plucked the flower out of his morning coat and closed his fist slowly over it , crushing <fex>it</fex> into a pulp.
<fex>The strong winds</fex> deformed the structure of the outhouse.
The lieutenant crushed it angrily with his boot <fex>before looking back at Hencke</fex>.
<fex>He</fex> insists on mispronouncing my name every time, the bastard!
My little nephew can't say <fex>prestidigitation</fex>
Finally, I would pay more attention to your 'oppinion' if you spelled it <fex>correctly</fex>.
The old uncensored editions of the Talmud referred to Jesus as Yeshua censored versions spelled it <fex>as Yeshu</fex>
You spelled it <fex>with a 't'</fex>.
You spelled it <fex>the way it sounds</fex>.
<fex>Today</fex> you spelled it 'pjuok'.
